div1.p: Wheeler cannot explain the loss of some letters from the Peabody material. She discusses the Kelly collection of photographs used in his publication Walter Reed and Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Helen Wheeler to Philip Showalter Hench, December 6, 1941
div1.opener:
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
WELCH MEDICAL LIBRARY
1900 EAST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD.
December 6, 1941.
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you for returning the rest of the material on yellow fever,
and also for sending the two reprints of your article, “Conquerors of
Yellow Fever.” I have passed one copy on to Dr. Sigerist as you requested.

You did call attention in an earlier letter to the fact that
some of the letters mentioned are missing from the Peabody material you had.
When Dr. Peabody left the package of material here, the staff member with
whom he left it understood that he was giving it to us merely for safe-
keeping and would return for it after a short time, so that it had nover
been opened, so far as we know, until I looked into it preparatory to sending
it to you. So it is hardly likely that the letters were lost here.

I am sorry I do not know whether the clippings were from the
Baltimore Sun or the New York Sun. As the package had not been opened,
no one here knew of its contents, and only one employee knew of the presence
of it in the library. Since you returned the material we have had cards
placed in the catalog indicating what and where it is, so that it will be
available to those interested.

Unfortunately the photographs which Dr. Kelly gave the Johns
Hopkins Hospital many years ago, and which came to this library when this
building was completed in 1929, have never been completely cataloged. I
have looked through them as well as I can in their present state, but have
found nothing else bearing on the yellow fever experiments except a photo-
graph of John R. Kissinger with the following memorandum, initialed by Dr.
Kelly, on the back: “Photo of John R. Kissinger, sent Feb. 25, 1912, quite
surely a reprod. from an older photo. Brought me by Dr. C. W. Latimer
8 Mch. 1912. H.A.K.” The photograph of Camp Lazear opposite page 146 in
the 1906 edition of Dr. Kelly's book, Walter Reed and Yellow Fever, is
identical with one in the material we sent you from Dr. Kelly's collection,
but I have not been able to find any others. I believe it is possible, how-
ever, to have copies made from illustrations in the book. This Kelly collection
of photographs is to be cataloged during this academic year, we hope, and if
anything comes to light that will interest you I shall be glad to send it on.
The partial catalog which we have does not reveal anything other than the
items you have already seen.

We greatly appreciate your own contributions to our material on
this subject.
